bibl.author: Richard Maurice Bucke
bibl.title: Richard Maurice Bucke to Walt Whitman, 3 November 1891
bibl.orgName: The Charles E. Feinberg Collection of the Papers of Walt Whitman, 1839–1919, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

revisionDesc.change: Second check: corrected transcription, added notes

body.p: Your letter of 31st Oct. just to hand and was glad to get it as also the long piece re Schliemann which I shall read as soon as I find a few minutes. Ross & Barber still both off duty, no one in their place and so I am pretty well tied up. I do not understand this last newspaper racket about your health. As far as I know (and I think I know as much as any one) you are abt. as you have been for the last three years (not getting any younger, but otherwise unchanged), the paralysis either not extending at all or so slowly that it's increase is imperceptible—as to the paralysis "going to the heart" that is all rubbish—paralysis cannot go to the heart. If you live untill the paralysis attacks the heart and so kills you you will live to be a thousand years old which is a fate I would not wish my best friend or worst enemy

closer.salute: I send you my love always
